captions.text:
Hello internet. A month ago when writing a
script for the previous video, I thought I

knew what internet love felt like, but the
launch of Subbable really knocked me off my

seat. The goal was to turn off pop-up ads,
and create some distance between us and the

advertising fairy. I thought it might take
weeks to achieve, if at all. But within five

hours, you made it so. Thank you. Since making
the project public, I've had lots of questions

and I am working on FAQ for the blog. For
now I want to address three points.

#1: Payments don't work. Yeah, so while Subbable
is awesome and you are awesome, having payments

break in less than a day and stay broken for
two weeks was, shall we say, a rather stressful

experience. The TL;DR is today everything's
fixed so if you wanted to help before but

were thwarted now it's good to go. You can
click above or below to head on over to Subbable,
unless you fall into point number two.

#2: I don't have any money and I feel guilty
for not helping. Okay, it's really important

to me that everyone know that I'm serious
about the "voluntary" part of the subscriptions.

If you want to support the channel but aren't
in a situation to do so, I'm officially absolving

you of all guilt right now. And if you're
in high school or six forms studying for the

SATS or OWLS or NEWTS or whatever, even if
you have a part-time job and cash to spare,

listen to me. Save your money. Put it in a
college fund, or toward professional training

or save it for a gap year. At this state of
your life, I don't want your money. I want

you to invest in yourself to improve your
own future. That might sound like the kind

of thing you might hear on an after-school
special, but I really mean it. Now assuming
the above does not apply to you, point three.

#3: ZOMG! The perk I want is sold out! Make
more! First, thank you to everyone who bought

a poster that had neither a design nor a size,
nor a ship date. The demand struck me as unreasonably

enthusiastic, but it was much appreciated.
So two things about Perks. First, because

this whole project is new, I'm not sure how
long it's going to take and how much it's

going to cost to get Perks like the poster
designed and printed and shipped to the warehouse

handling all of this. Then sent to me to sign,
and shipped back to the warehouse to be sent

to you. With so much uncertainty, I don't
want to make a thousand people angry if it

takes longer than expected. But when the poster
does arrive at your door, you'll know that

it's already quite fashionably traveled transcontinental.
Second, the idea at Subbable is to make it

work long term, so the posters and other perks
are not a one-time sale. Sold-out perks will

reset monthly mostly, so if you missed out
on the first round any subscriptions you made

thus far will count toward future perks. Subbable
works like this to try and keep monthly funding

at or above 100% so we can keep the advertising
fairy consistently disappointed, not just
push him away once.

So those are the big points. It's been an
exciting, though stressful, start. I think

Subbable is going to work and it's going to
be better for everyone. Alright, I've got

to go. There are postcards to write and posters
to approve and tons of other stuff to do.
Thank you again, and I'll see you later internet.
